1. BE EXCELLENT TO EACH OTHER.
2. PARTY ON, DUDES. (AND DUDETTES)

>>>DRAWTHREAD RULES<<<

>Requesters:
• Provide good, detailed references (pictures are better than verbal descriptions), so the artists know what you're looking for.
• Only bump your request once every 24 hours. Don't bump WIPs.
• If you have a WIP quote the Anchor Post, and attach the WIP so your drawfag can find you.
• Do not reply to other deliveries with a request that the artist fill your request next, this is called 'piggybacking'.
• Do not make multiple requests in the same thread and do not serially request multiple characters after a delivery. Suggesting several concepts for artists to choose from counts as making multiple requests.
• If you're unsatisfied with your completed request, please wait at least one week before you re-request. If someone follows this rule, don't waste posts by complaining about it.
• Reminder that nobody is entitled to a delivery under any circumstances within these threads. Don't critique others' requests. If you don't like it, don't draw it.
• Stay on topic. This thread has been deleted twice!

Requesting a green ranger inspired dual-shield tank.

The party in my game needs a tank so I decided to make a dual-shield tank build to accompany them. With the recent loss of one of my heroes I decided to make this character a bit of a tribute as well. Here's the brief of his look.

> Bulky humanoid figure, no unusual racial features showing.
> Heavy bulky armor, never removes any of it. Face is always hidden.
> Dual shields, turtle styled, either paired halves or not, preferably about the size of a standard kite shield.
> Green Ranger inspired, heavily.
> Dragon Turtle inspiration.
> Regional styles (weeb/european/etc) up to artist's discretion as long as it's fantasy.

I didn't want to do a campy copypasta reference, just want to make the character heavily inspired by the original Green Ranger and easily recognizable as such while still being somewhat unique in design. Sort of like a "non-copyright infringing" version. Please and thank you.

I have a pic I can use for a placeholder now but I'd still like something original so it's less of a cheap insert and more of a solid character and reference.

>>86841039
Let's go thru each line/splat. I am presuming that they have predated themselves for the occasion, as >>86840817 implied.
>Vampire: The Requiem
Most vampires would get cozy do nothing jobs because of their political connections and preparations. Obliviously, there would be plenty of incidents of vampires getting killed by hunters presuming that they have the law on their side, those would be rarer now that feeding can be better organized with a bigger mortal population.
>Werewolf: The Forsaken
I doubt that their revelation would be to the benefit of the tribe. They would be, at best, spirit specialists in some sort of interdimensional border patrol with military backup. At worst, humanity ends up killing the majority of new werewolves as humanity develops a way to track and kill spirit related threats.
>Mage: The Awakening
Reality goes to shit because of mass awakenings and the Exarchs enforcing their influence in a direct manner as Abyssal creatures flood the material world.
>Promethean: The Created
Again, most of them would die because of their nature. However, some organizations would be more than willing to help them to travel between their Hovels, at least initially.
>Changeling: The Lost
They get sent back to Brazil, as their Keepers and Huntsmen have an easier time tracking those who escape Arcadia.
>Geist: The Sin-Eaters
After no less than 87 schisms and 12 civil wars because of the religious implications of their existence, they become a major influence in both sides as the main way of contacting the dead, riches flood the underworld and their pockets as many people would give almost anything to talk with their departed loved ones.
>Mummy: The Curse
I don't know shit about them.
>Demon: The Descent

last_replies.com: An arboreal fantasy world heavily inspired by Arthurian Legends, Swamp Thing, Celtic Mythology, and Lord of the Rings. In the setting, all magic comes from nature and it's considered to be divine, so most druids also assume the role of the clergy. Most of the races of the setting have some kind of "divine essence" except for the humans, which are the newest race to come into existence, due to this they often are looked upon and underestimated by the oldest races which are either made of Plants (like the Treants, Dryads and 'Satyrs") or Fungi (like Myconids or Pookas/Vegpygmies/Goblins/I still haven't decided what to call them). For now, I want to tell a story more focused on the human side of things since I feel more secure doing it first but I will develop more about the other species as time goes on.

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

threads.com:
>"GMing homebrew? Awesome, tell me about the cool lore of your homebrew world, make me psyched to have adventures in it."
>"Well you see there's the Kingdom of Nildor, then the Theocracy of Borovind, the United Cledean Principalities, the Four Baronies, the Matriarchy of Homind. The Nildorians are sort of like Spaniards, but..."


I need you all to stop doing this. Seriously. The players do not give one smidgeon of a fuck about the political structure of your world if you have -nothing else- of interest happening in it. They're adventurers. They're not there to try to find some excitement in your badly-written historical documentary, they're there for the actual story informed by the bullshit you wrote.

I'm not saying don't write political lore, but don't front it to your players and expect them to be wowed by it. It's a building block, not the finished product. Why the fuck do you guys draw a map, colour in some countries, give them a bunch of retarded, clumsy names, decide which one of them is going to be an Elf nation that just acts like all the rest of them, and then call it a setting, call it done?

Then inevitably when the first session finally occurs, none of it matters, because we're still Level 1 mooks in a tavern who are going to have to crawl into a cave and murder some goblins for the local blacksmith.

Because of movement speed limitations, Jump is near enough useless if you have 20str already because each foot of jump costs 1 foot of movement.

Long jump horizontal movement
- standing: 10ft jump
- running start: 10ft run + 20ft jump
- standing w/ Jump: 30ft jump
- running start w/ Jump: 10ft run + 20ft jump
- Real Life world record long jump w/ running start: 29ft 4.25inch
- running start w/Jump if 5e wasn't shit: 10ft run + 60ft jump

High Jump vertical movement
- standing: 4ft jump
- running start: 8ft jump
- standing w/ Jump: 12ft
- running start w/ Jump: 20ft (10ft running start caps vertical movement to 20)
- Real Life world record high jump w/ running start: 8ft
- w/o 5e movement cap: 24ft

>What is Kingdom Death: Monster?
Monster is a Survival Horror Co-Op board game for 1-4 players about hope in a truly dark place. You awaken in a plane of stone faces bathed in eternal darkness known as the Kingdom Death, a place full of freaky (and sometimes psycho-sexual) monstrosities.

Prologue Narration: [YouTube] Kingdom Death: Monster - Prologue (embed)

The Game is broken up into 3 phases:
1. During your Hunt Phase your band of survivors traverse the world of KD in pursuit of their quarry.
2. After successfully tracking your quarry you will begin the Showdown Phase, where you must fell these horrific creatures in order to acquire precious resources.
3. After the battle, your survivors wander home with loot in hand to begin the Settlement Phase. Arm yourself by developing new weapons and bizarre structures to prepare for next year's hunt.

A successful game campaign takes place over the course of 25 to 30 'lantern years' maximum, marked by completing one full phase cycle. Watch as your settlement grows and witness the survivors write their own narrative as they age. Hone your strategy and learn from your mistakes to overcome the immense odds in this cruel and twisted nightmare scape.

>tl;dr
It's basically Darkest Dungeon meets Monster Hunter meets Berserk.

How do you make/what has made caves interesting places to adventure?
In real life there's the inherent physical challenge, not unlike climbing a mountain, the awe of discover that you're in a place few have ever seen before, and while the geological features may be, the ecosystems that exist within deep caves, however minimal it may be, while fascinating, are hardly the subject of vivid descriptions and fantastical tales.

Realistically how would complex life survive completely isolated from the surface in it's own underground world?
Though since this is fantasy I will accept "magic" as an answer as long as the explanation has sufficient thought put into it.

>>86837542
Diff. It’s deeper than that. Heinlein didn’t make characters, he made mouthpieces. The actual character is immersed in war, and should clearly worry on how it effects them PERSONALLY. Simple desires are twisted and torn from possibility, by the unavoidable white elephant — interstellar warfare. Your desire for glory is meaningless on such a grand scale, grunt. The radical time-wrought change in the homestead is magnified, given the human propensity for short-sightedness. Will your insurance still cover your family in 30, what exactly are you getting out of the godforsaken decade-eating suicide mission you signed up for? Heinlein only cared about plot effects and responses that propped up his characters — even so far as to use temporality-generated incest as a ‘rightful’ reward. The reward for being a political theory puppet.

Normal shit like: running out of materials, having to improvise high-sci dumbassery and crossing your fingers, spending large amounts of time confused — while in high risk situation... Basic and common vicissitudes of military life don’t apply or matter. Not to Heinlein. Because the military is only seen by Heinlein as a useful prop for some grandiose incestuous government — not as a subject in and of itself. The difference in scale unironically reduces the detailed impact of military life.

>mudcore: only medieval peasant are playable

>free-for-all: All playable races, all cultures, all religions. Better start coming up with an explanation, GM.

>>86808521
Okina is the Touhou version of Matara-jin, a god of a bunch of things including outcasts and performers. In her first appearance she spends her whole fight sitting on a comfy chair, but stands up for the rematch where she fights at full power (the idea that her full power is just standing up is poked fun at). She also has two minions invested with a portion of her power, whom she calls "my hands and feet".

In later appearances the wheelchair is introduced, but she's sometimes shown walking around too. Seems like she can walk but it takes a lot of effort (like how most characters can fly but usually travel by foot). The weird part is that one manga showed Okina flying *while* in the wheelchair.

Also, Touhou is set in modern times and Okina is capable of viewing the world outside Gensokyo so she'd be familiar with what a wheelchair is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Don't have NPCs join the party. This is a bad move. It doesn't matter if you call it a DMPC or not.

People will tell you that it's not necessarily a bad idea, and they're right, but it's a bad idea for you. You told us that your brothers are new players, and it sounds like you're a new GM, so you should just focus on playing the dungeon and let them play the PCs.

If you want to give them an advantage you can give them and reusable healing item of some kind. But that makes them game easier-and-more-complicated. Then you use harder challenges to compensate and the game gets even more complicated. Conversely, if you grant no healing items and just use lesser challenges then the game is easier and simpler and that's what you want. You control both sides of the line here, so there's certainly no reason to roll a whole new character and run it for them and then compensate with an extra monster that you also have to run, that's just silly.

>>86831906
As an Autist who has used both PTU and PTA I can give details.
Physical tabletop is impossible for both. Roll 20 has very good built in sheets.
PTA got very weird as PTA 3e went into a whole new direction where your Mon are a lot less customizable but more slimmed down. So now you get to compare PTA 2e, PTU, and PTA 3e.
PTA 2e is bit , but this is also a positive as you can get powerful combos with relative simplicity. but you have to precalculate at least 6 different die rolls for 6 different characters. And each move effectively has a unique damage roll you have to keep note of And don't get me started on the class advancement. Something like a 9th of all the classes are dedicated to Pokemon contests. The game never bothers to actually explain how to run contests.
But PTA 2e has the absolute best online tool You can quickly and easily generate encounters just from your browser. You can even calculate damage right on it.
But I don't even know where you can download PTA 2e now,

PTU reworked classes from being 9 core classes and 50ish sub classes to having a bunch of classes you can go to and fro from.

They balanced the moves, which makes it more forgiving, but also slows things down. Moves with less damage, you multiply your stats by 1.20 stead 1.25, Multitarget moves are fewer, you can actually use speed to dodge moves as an effective investment. IF you don't want to slow things down you have to deal with the additional 'injuries' mechanic, which just adds even more crunch to punish heal spam, but that I consider optional until they start to heal spam. They do at least replace the unique damage dice with "damage base". which you get from the move's normal damage and convert it a chart. And you can even just replace the damage roll with a fixed number the "DB" has to save time.
Building humans somehow got more complex, having 2 different types of feat to spend. But used increasing d6's for skill rolls, which is a plus.

>>86831906
As the resident DDA Shill, I'm not sure it fits what OP wants since as has been noted it aims to emulate the anime where collecting is less of a thing (except in Xros Wars but fuck Xros Wars, Xros Wars was dogshit and I want to choke shoutmon to death with a hot fire poker down his throat).

Good system, but it's not exactly built for "monster collection" or "taming and using monsters rather than cutting them all down". Pokemon really does fit the collection/taming aspect more than digimon, so I'll leave those games to others mostly since there seem to be experts on those systems in the thread.

I have however run Pokerole, and unfortunately it's not great. It's not bad but it's a bit janky because the author(s?) is/are ESL so a lot of important info (such as training successes being cumulative rather than having to all be hit in one go) not being in the book. It also doesn't clearly articulate how the action economy works very well. In a lot of ways, it's similar to West End Games' d6 star wars; fun system, shitty rulebook. Once you overcome the janky book it's fun enough though and considering how I've seen PTU and PTA described in this thread and others is my go-to pokemon system because I'm not psychotic enough (yet) to make my own.


So, TLDR, if you want to lean harder into the raising/taming/battling aspect:
>Monsters and Other Childish Things for the generic option
>PTU/PTA/Pokerole for Pokemon, as to your taste

If you want to lean harder into humans fighting alongside monster friends with a more narrative/character focused bent and everyone at the table has some GMing experience/can play 2 PCs at once:
>DDA

>>86831273
>>86834979
I'm in the same position, just with slightly diffent elements. I'm tackling it by going very, very soft on what constitues and element and not doing any hard lock-in for mages.

You get your innate magic fusing with a spirit, trading away a part of your being. An eye, a certain skill, memories, or whatever the spirit fancied. But beyond that you can still make pacts with whatever spirits, just more in an exchange-of-goods-and-services manner.

The different elements are really more metaphysical principles that happen to manifest into the material world as what we recognize as fire, water, etc. What those themes are is based on the mythological creatures that I used as basis for the spirits.
Now, no "proper" mage would limit themselves to one element. Pyromancers exist for sure, but those are a bunch of dragon-obsessed weirdoes and not certified by the Tower.
It's not that you have Healing, because that that's a Light thing. No, you are a healer, and you will use whatever it takes to save your patients, magic or mundane. Water + Light lets you keep fighting with a hole in your chest, Earth borrows vitality from your comrades, Fire closes the hole and Wind makes you better at surviving holes in the chest, because you previously survived holes in the chest. It's just kinda your thing.

>but I want single element casters
The single best tip I can give you is to not limit yourself to a materialistic perspective what each element can do. That will inevitably cause an imbalance, because as it turned out our observations on the fundamental nature of reality from 3000 years ago were not entirely accurate.

Cont.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86839481
Ask yourself, what really is fire? Scientifically, it's not a thing at all, it's a process. That can't be an element, but it works great as an analogy. What powers work kinda like fire does? What protects us from the cold? What gives us better food? What allows us to conquer the night?
Likewise, just what is void? Is it nothing, or is it endless possibility? Is it not the unknown, where all answers to our questions lie? Or is it a place full of hideous un-things that should not be, whose very presence brings only ruin?
Aether is the element of the heavens, where the stars reside. Stars where important for navigation and time keeping, and some claim to read fate from them. What can you do with that?
And so forth with the other ones. Don't try to add two elements to an existing system, rethink it from the ground up for your six elements.


Here's some characters I've had with soft element powers in different settings. Feel free to steal anything that looks good.

>Rust
He could make stuff rust of course, but he also could give people tetanus' muscle spasms. And because rust is "silent fire" he was also really sneaky.

>Metal
That man was "a friend of all things metal". He could shape metal in any way he pleased and control its temperature, but more importantly it would not harm him. Took a bullet to the head and woke up ten minutes later with a migraine.

>Negation
He used it to float(not fly, float) around and look aloof all the time, because no attacks could hit him.

>Void Dragon
The breath stripped all properties from living flesh, leaving behind only pure energy that solidified into mana crystals. Financed a war on his own.

>Gravity
Made himself an Ironman suit out of used cars that he controlled with incredibly strong, isolated gravitational fields. When he got his hands on some helium canisters he detonated a fusion bomb in the final boss' face, even saying "let there be light".
Also teamed up with the Lightning guy by creating a giant coilgun.

Barebones run down of the six elements & the most common abilities, more than what I have here comes up though.

Air >superspeed & flight
Water >disguising, empathy, healing (using big tubs of water to contain hemorages
Earth >superstrength, farming, & lustful emotions
Fire >fireballs & inspiring emotions
Wood >camouflage, farming, & archery skill
Metal >painkilling & sword skill

No ice furies, but there is ice magic, used by yetis in the north.

As for how bloodlines & furies & such interact... its complicated. The book even talks about how the scholars debate about the nature of furies. What we DO know is that furies are spirits of the land those in civilized places seem to be less powerful than those on the frontier lands. Every human bonds with at least one fury around puberty, nobles tend to have more elements & usually have more powerful furies. Furies can be inherited, & wild furies can be claimed.

>>86839687
Let's go a little further than >>86839714 did and compare things a bit. Because of how basic zombies work, they can't have Improved Bull Rush or Improved Overrun, but even if they did Overrun always starts by risking an AoO. Then Overrun, if resisted, lets the opponent use the better of Dex or Str to resist. It also keeps the formation the same, and so you can end up risking more AoOs since you're still moving in and out of threatened squares. A successful Bull Rush can move the formation around, you don't have to follow, but if you do then you have the opportunity to move things around more. You can also immediately trigger an AoO from a nearby friend with a bull rush, though an overrun that knocks down also has that potential, just later on.

My setting is somewhat similar to Jack Vance's Dying Earth, or Michael Moorcock's setting, in that it's set very long after a post-apocalyptic sci-fi Earth. East of old Istanbul, now the City-State of Blackhilt, is the remains of an empire from a thousand years ago now called the Blasted Wastes. Ancient arcane libraries and crypts full of undead and aberrations lie partially sunken beneath the dunes. Magically amplified sandstorms can literally tear the flesh from your bones.

The geography is comprised of the ruins of the crumbling Pontic Mountains and swaths of desert terrain, and expands throughout most of the land once known, in ages long past, as Anatolia. Gnolls and Thri-Kreen are the most populous intelligent species roaming the surface, taking shelter in the ruins of old dwellings and bathhouses by night and warring for meagre resources and territory by day. A few particularly hardy sub-breeds of orcs live in tribes or small warring chiefdoms in the shadows and warrens of the mountains. Far worse things live below.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
A Fames (FA-mays) begins life as a fungal spore. If ingested by a warm-blooded animal, the Fames will be absorbed through the digestive system in the usual way; a very few will survive to enter the bloodstream. If at least one of them survives the body's immune system and finds its way to the brain, it will lodge in the endocrine system and begin to grow. This is the first stage and takes about a day for a typical adult human.

Subtly at first, the colony compromises the host's immune system and begins to alter it's behaviour by making it constantly hungry. The excess energy/nutrients ingested will feed the growth of the Fames and, after a day or so, the production of spores which are excreted through urine or faeces to potentially infect others. This is the second stage and lasts for up to a week.

As the Fames grows, it will begin to replace other parts of the host's nervous system. The Third stage is marked by the host suffering headaches and nightmares, which (in humans) lasts for up to two days before suddenly stopping. The host is now completely under the Fames control and effectively no longer exists. This will lead to increasingly aberrant behaviour as it single-mindedly consumes as much food as possible AND attempts to infect others. Fames hosts will seek to infect food and water supplies and carry out more and more sophisticated and/or brutal strategies to infect more and more warm-blooded hosts.

Eventually, the host's head will become deformed and its behaviour completely abnormal for its species. If it has survived to this point, the original Fames is the leader - and ONLY entity allowed to release spores - of a small community of Fames. Hosts progressively degenerate physically through vulnerability to other infections and die: if human, after about three months.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>86837934
The fact that mythical beings are often said to inhabit 'exotic' locations doesn't mean that the actual inhabitants of those places served as inspiration for them.
It's very common for monsters in folklore to live in 'hostile territory' or far away. For example, Jack the Giant Killer encounters giants mostly in Wales, because he is an English hero. Many German romances feature Saracen giants, encountered either in Spain or the Middle East. Icelanders encountered witches and trolls in the Orkneys. Ancient Greeks thought the monstrous races were found in Africa and India. That doesn't mean that muslims (for example) were especially big people who inspired stories of giants. It just means that people like to think of monsters as being foreign, probably because it helps with suspension of disbelief if they aren't encountered in familiar territory, with demonization of enemies being a nice bonus.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Many of us know the usual Blood War gimmick in a D&D context: demons and devils clashing on a massive and multiversal scale, often using whole mortal worlds as their battlefields. There might be yugoloths running around as some mix of mercenaries, profiteers, and manipulators. (In Eberron, this might instead be a clash between multiple simultaneously released fiendish overlords, some of which did not quite get along.)

But what if we add a wild card to the mix, something none of these fiends even remotely expect? Desperate times call for desperate measures. When the whispers of cosmic, aberrant powers promise salvation to a besieged world, who is to refuse them? Whether these eldritch forces are Mak Thuum Ngatha and Ragnorra, Caiphon and Allabar, Dyrrn and Belashyrra, Cthulhu and Shub-Niggurath, or some other mix of entities, they are willing to empower vast cults and lend a hand against the fiendish invaders. (In 13th Age, the Crusader wages war against demons, and the "dark gods" he is pledged to could very well be aberrant!) What happens if the fiends are driven away? Well, the world can work that out later, right?

As an alternative scenario, it could be that the forces originally plaguing the world are spooky aberrations to begin with. Then, fiendish powers start to offer their aid, establishing cults across the globe to drive back all the tentacles and extraneous eyeballs.

How would you run an adventure or a campaign which pits fiends (no pun intended) and aberrations against one another? What sort of interesting scenarios could PCs get involved in?

In 13th Age's Book of Ages, one of the more notable historical figures is the Astrologer:
>The Astrologer ruled over the holy city of Santa Cora in this age. She argued that arcane science was superior to belief in the gods; through complex calculations and prognostications, she could isolate and shape the destiny of an individual. Later in the age, she suppressed the worship of the gods in favor of worship of the Terrible Emperor, and used her astrological powers to rob people of their natural destiny and force different fates onto them, locking them into service of the throne. The first victim of this manipulation of destiny was the Archmage.

The Astrologer made the Terrible Emperor and his dreaded Pearl Legion immune to the touch of time, and fated to never fall to weapons and spells. However, she neglected to foresee a major loophole: unarmed attacks do not count as "weapons." This allowed the Grandmaster of Flowers to lead an order of monks and overthrow the Terrible Emperor and his Pearl Legion.

In mechanical terms, the unaging remnants of the Pearl Legion are very difficult to bring to 0 hit points with weapons or spells. However, unarmed attacks can finish them off just fine.

All it is is putting points into a class, which gets you abilities related to that class, then you can choose to promote out of that class into another.

In 2e you have specific classes you promote into and out of (career exits and entries). In 4e you have a more linear career path but can try to change careers.

I don't know. Doesn't seem that great to me. I mean, I like it but I wouldn't go touting it as anything special.

Not OP either, but I like the same stuff as this guy:
>>86837576
and also:
You get a real sense of your character as someone who fits into the setting, with an actual job, which often reinforces the mudcore genre (e.g. it's entirely possible to start as a ratcatcher, beggar, prostitute, etc.) in a way you might not have chosen if you had free reign to make the character according to your own wishes.

As for systems with a similar feel, I think Burning Wheel does it OK, although the emphasis on cramming everything into fairly small tables means there isn't quite as much flavour and it's a lot less intuitive to use.

Not Cao anon, but yeah, combat is useful for leveling up. 'There is great terror in the line between life and death, but also great fortune'. Or something like that. For most people, closing up to meditate, and going out to adventure are both necessary components for increasing their realm. Some people, especially the really pacifist types can get by without exploration (but they tend to be weaker). Some people, like Hu Ling'er, can get by without the quiet meditation part, relying entirely on going from one battlefield from another, which is more dangerous due to all the combat.
As a rule, the more dangerous and stressful a fight is, the more beneficial it is.
